revision.text:
{{Other people}} {{Infobox comedian | name=Pete Holmes | image=Pete Holmes performing at Meltdown.jpg | imagesize=220px | caption=Holmes performing at Meltdown Comics on January 2, 2013 | birth_name=Peter Benedict Holmes | birth_date={{birth date and age|1979|3|30}} | birth_place=[[Lexington, Massachusetts]], U.S. | other_names= | medium=Stand-up, television, film, podcast | genre=[[Improvisational comedy]], [[observational comedy]], [[sketch comedy]], [[blue comedy]], [[surreal humor]], [[sarcasm]], [[satire]] | subject= | active=2001–present | alma_mater = [[Gordon College (Massachusetts)|Gordon College]] | notable_work=''[[CollegeHumor]]''
''[[You Made It Weird with Pete Holmes]]''
''[[The Pete Holmes Show]]''
''[[Crashing (U.S. TV series)|Crashing]] | domestic_partner= | website=[http://www.peteholmes.com/ PeteHolmes.com] | academyawards= | spouse=Valerie Chaney (m. 2017) | module = }} '''Peter Benedict Holmes''' (born March 30, 1979) is an American comedian, actor, writer, producer, and podcaster. ==Early life== Holmes was born in [[Lexington, Massachusetts]]. He attended [[Lexington High School (Massachusetts)|Lexington High School]] and [[Gordon College (Massachusetts)|Gordon College]] in [[Wenham, Massachusetts]]. In college, he majored in English and Communications, and he participated in an [[improvisational comedy]] troupe, The Sweaty-Toothed Madmen. Holmes got married at 22, the same age at which he began performing stand-up comedy, and he divorced at 28,{{cite web|last1=Ryan|first1=Patric|title=How divorce led Pete Holmes to HBO's 'Crashing'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2017/02/16/pete-holmes-crashing-hbo-judd-apatow/97949544/|website=USA Today|accessdate=8 March 2017}} after his then wife had an affair.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/magazine/2018/01/17/how-lexington-evangelical-got-judd-apatow-attention-and-became-hbo-comedy-star/AfhUWn5mVKZTqyzxIZ3xkJ/story.html|title=How Lexington’s Pete Holmes got Judd Apatow’s attention and became a comedy star - The Boston Globe|last=Swidey|first=Neil|date=January 17, 2018|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2018-04-06|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Finding little success, he lived in [[Sleepy Hollow, New York]] and [[Chicago]] before moving to [[Los Angeles]]. ==Career== Holmes has appeared on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Premium Blend]]'', as a regular panelist on [[VH1]]'s ''[[Best Week Ever]]'', and on VH1's ''All Access''.{{IMDb name|2803399|Pete Holmes}} His [[cartoons]] have appeared in ''[[The New Yorker]]''.Kharakh, Ben. [[Interview]], [http://gothamist.com/2006/10/26/pete_holmes_com.php "Pete Holmes, Comedian"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418004746/http://gothamist.com/2006/10/26/pete_holmes_com.php |date=2008-04-18 }}, ''Gothamist'', 26 October 2006. In 2010, he performed on ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand Up Show]]'' as well as ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]''. On February 26, 2010, he performed his first television special on the series ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]''. On March 21, 2011 and on November 17, 2011, he appeared on the [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] talk show ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''. Holmes has provided the voices for several of the characters on Comedy Central's cartoon ''[[Ugly Americans (TV series)|Ugly Americans]]''. He was the voice of the [[E-Trade]] baby on several [[television commercial]]s and was also credited as a writer for those commercials.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704422204576130400671315430|title=The Funny People Behind the Famous Ads|last=Steinberg|first=Don|date=2011-02-18|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} He wrote for the [[NBC]] primetime sitcom ''[[Outsourced (TV series)|Outsourced]]'' and also wrote for the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] sitcom ''[[I Hate My Teenage Daughter]]'' prior to its [[cancellation (television)|cancellation]] in May 2012.{{Cite news|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/11/crashing-trailer-pete-holmes-hbo-sitcom-judd-apatow-1201749079/|title=‘Crashing’ Trailer: Pete Holmes’ HBO Sitcom Shows The Comic Adjusting To Divorced Life|last=Murthi|first=Vikram|date=2016-11-22|work=IndieWire|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-US}} Holmes released his first album, ''[[Impregnated With Wonder]]'', on [[iTunes]] on November 15, 2011.{{cite web|last=Harris |first=Will |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-best-comedy-albums-of-2011,66251 |title=The best comedy albums of 2011 | Music | Best of |publisher=The A.V. Club |date=2011-12-08 |accessdate=2013-10-22}} In 2013, he released his second album, ''[[Nice Try, The Devil]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/the-best-comedy-albums-and-specials-of-2013-106128|title=The best comedy albums and specials of 2013|first=Kevin|last=McFarland|date=|website=avclub.com}} Holmes has created a popular comedic portrayal of [[Batman]] in [[CollegeHumor]]'s internet series ''Badman.'' He also ran a YouTube channel which was focused around skits alongside [[Matt McCarthy (comedian)|Matthew McCarthy]] called frontpagefilms.[https://www.youtube.com/user/frontpagefilms frontpagefilms] on YouTube Holmes created and stars in the HBO series, ''[[Crashing (U.S. TV series)|Crashing]].'' The pilot was written by Holmes and directed by [[Judd Apatow]]. HBO renewed the series for a second season on March 15, 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/crashing-pete-holmes-comedy-renewed-season-2-1202009571/|title=HBO Renews Pete Holmes Comedy ‘Crashing’ for Second Season|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|date=2017-03-15|work=Variety|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en-US}} Holmes is currently writing a book on religion.{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2017/april-web-only/pete-holmes-believing-in-god-gave-me-hope-as-comic.html|title=Pete Holmes: Believing in God Gave Me Hope as Comic|author=|date=|website=christianitytoday.com}} ===''You Made It Weird with Pete Holmes''=== {{Main|You Made It Weird with Pete Holmes}} Holmes hosts a podcast titled, ''[[You Made It Weird with Pete Holmes|You Made It Weird]]''. It has featured guests such as [[Garry Shandling]], [[Judd Apatow]], [[Aziz Ansari]], [[John Mulaney]], and [[Dana Carvey]]. Topics typically discussed in each episode are the guests' views on comedy, sexuality, and religion. ===''The Pete Holmes Show''=== {{Main|The Pete Holmes Show}} On August 21 and 23 in 2012, Holmes recorded three episodes of a talk show pilot for TBS, produced by [[Conan O'Brien]], entitled ''The Midnight Show with Pete Holmes''.{{cite web|title=Get Free Tickets For The Pilot Of "The Midnight Show With Pete Holmes"|url=http://teamcoco.com/peteholmes|accessdate=20 August 2012}}{{cite news|title=Pete Holmes To Follow Conan O'Brien? Talk Show Pilot In Development At TBS|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/25/pete-holmes-follow-conan-obrien-tbs_n_1703999.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Ross|last=Luippold|date=July 25, 2012}} Holmes's guests on the unaired pilots included [[Nick Offerman]], [[Joel McHale]], [[T. J. Miller]], and [[Bill Burr]]. On February 26, 2013, TBS picked up the show and began airing in fall 2013. It showcased "the comedian’s incredible skill set, combining sketches, short films, live comedy, field pieces and in-studio guest interviews into a fast-paced half hour."{{cite web|title=TBS Greenlights Conan O'Brien-Produced Late-Night Show Starring Pete Holmes As 'Conan' Companion - Deadline.com|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/02/tbs-orders-conan-obrien-produced-late-night-show-starring-pete-holmes-as-conan-companion/}} As of July 10, 2013 the name of the show was ''[[The Pete Holmes Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nerdist.com/2013/07/you-made-it-weird-166-johnny-pemberton/ |title=You Made It Weird #166: Johnny Pemberton « Nerdist |publisher=Nerdist.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-22}} The series premiered on October 28, right after ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''. The show was picked up for a second season by TBS. On December 9, 2013, Gabe Liedman performed the show's first-ever stand-up routine.{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2013/12/gabe-liedman-was-pete-holmes-shows-first-ever-standup-last-night/|title=Gabe Liedman Was 'Pete Holmes Show's First-Ever Standup Last Night - Splitsider|work=Splitsider|accessdate=16 January 2015}} On May 23, 2014, TBS canceled the talk show after two seasons following poor audience ratings. The show ended its run on June 19, 2014.[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/tbs-cancels-pete-holmes-show-706824 "TBS Cancels 'The Pete Holmes Show' After Two Seasons (Exclusive)"], ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/05/tbs-cancels-pete-holmes-show-735296/|title=TBS Cancels ‘The Pete Holmes Show’|website=Deadline.com|date=23 May 2014|accessdate=15 November 2017}} ===''Crashing''=== {{Main|Crashing (U.S. TV series)}} Crashing is a semi-autobiographical show on [[HBO]] that revolves around Holmes' character Pete, a young comedian who pursues a career in stand-up comedy after his wife cheats on him, leaving him homeless. Holmes successfully pitched the idea of the show to [[Judd Apatow]] and it was picked up by HBO for filming in September 2015, with Apatow as director. The success of the pilot led HBO to give the [[green-light]] to the first season in January 2016. After four episodes had aired, HBO renewed the series for a second season.{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/03/hbo-renews-pete-holmes-crashing-for-season-two.html|title=Paste Magazine|author=|date=|website=pastemagazine.com}} ===''Badman''=== {{Main|CollegeHumor}} Holmes portrays the lead character Batman in this [[parody]] [[web series]]. The series recreates scenes from [[Christopher Nolan]]'s Batman films with a comedic twist, such as Batman appearing completely incompetent or sex-obsessed. ==Influences== Holmes has listed [[Brian Regan (comedian)|Brian Regan]], [[Sinbad (comedian)|Sinbad]], [[Steve Martin]], [[Conan O'Brien]], [[Jerry Seinfeld]], [[Chris Farley]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dBjCLD1AWMs|title=#MeetPete Facebook Questions|work=YouTube|accessdate=16 January 2015}} [[Dane Cook]],{{cite web|url=http://www.nerdist.com/2013/03/you-made-it-weird-135-dane-cook/|title=You Made It Weird|work=Nerdist|accessdate=16 January 2015}} and [[Ray Romano]]{{cite web|url=http://nerdist.com/you-made-it-weird-212-ray-romano//|title=You Made It Weird|work=Nerdist|accessdate=21 April 2016}} as his biggest influences that got him into comedy. == Personal life == Holmes married Valerie Chaney, whom he refers to as “Sweet Lady Val,” in late 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.avclub.com/pete-holmes-says-being-married-changes-things-1820541531|title=Pete Holmes says being married changes things|author=Baraka Kaseko and Marah Eakin|publisher=AV Club|accessdate=January 11, 2018}} On April 3, 2018, Chaney announced via Instagram that the couple were expecting their first child, a girl. == Discography == * ''[[Impregnated With Wonder]]'' (2011) * ''[[Nice Try, The Devil]]'' (2013) * ''The Extended Play E.P.'' by [[T.J. Miller]] (featured on "Battle Of The Century, Part II") * ''Faces & Sounds'' (2017) == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2014 | ''[[I Am Road Comic]]'' | Himself | |- | 2016 | ''[[Don't Think Twice]]'' | Pete Holmes | Cameo appearance |- | 2018 | ''Gutbuster'' | Himself | Post-production |- | 2019 | ''[[The Secret Life of Pets 2]]'' | Merrick (voice) | |- |} === Television === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2005 | ''[[Premium Blend]]'' | Himself | Episode: "8.6" |- | 2007 | ''Scott Batman Presents Scott Batman Presents'' | Earth's New Robot Overlord (voice) | Episode: "One" |- | 2010 | ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]'' | Himself | Stand-up Special |- | 2010–11 | ''[[Outsourced (TV series)|Outsourced]]'' | | Writer |- | 2010–13 | ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand-Up Show]]'' | Himself | 3 episodes |- | 2010–12 | ''[[Ugly Americans (TV series)|Ugly Americans]]'' | Toby (voice) | 20 episodes |- | 2011–12 | ''[[I Hate My Teenage Daughter]]'' | | Writer |- | 2013 | ''[[The Jeselnik Offensive]]'' | Himself | Episode 1.9 |- | 2013 | ''[[Maron (TV series)|Maron]]'' | Himself | Episode: "Marc's Dad" |- | 2013 | ''Pete Holmes: [[Nice Try, The Devil|Nice Try, the Devil!]]'' | Himself | Stand-up Special |- | 2013 | ''[[American Dad!]]'' | Toby (voice), Millionaire Matt Davis (voice) | Episode: "[[Lost in Space (American Dad!)|Lost in Space]]" "[[American Dad! (season 9)|The Longest Distance Relationship]]" |- | 2013–14 | ''[[The Pete Holmes Show]]'' | Himself (host) | Also creator, writer, and executive producer |- | 2014 | ''[[Mulaney]]'' | Trey | Episode: "In the Name of the Mother, and the Son, and the Holy Andre" |- | 2016 | ''[[Animals.]]'' | Patrick (voice) | Episode: "Rats." |- | 2016 | ''Pete Holmes: Faces and Sounds''{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2016/11/watch-a-promo-for-pete-holmess-hbo-standup-special-faces-and-sounds/|title=Pete Holmes HBO Standup Special Faces and Sounds|work=Splitsider|accessdate=12 November 2016}} | Himself | Stand-up Special |- | 2017–present | ''[[Crashing (U.S. TV series)|Crashing]]'' | Pete | Also creator, writer, and executive producer |- | 2016-present | ''[[Mighty Magiswords]]'' | Teri Gargantuan, Thaddeus Thirdwell III (voice) | 4 episodes |- | 2017 | ''[[Penn Zero: Part-Time Hero]]'' | Ryan (voice) | Episode: "A Tale of Two Wizards" |- |} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|2803399|Pete Holmes}} * [http://www.frontpagefilms.com/ Front Page Films] * {{Twitter}} * [https://www.youtube.com/user/peteholmes/ Pete Holmes' YouTube Channel] *[http://www.peteholmes.com/ Pete Holmes Official Website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holmes, Pete}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:American television talk show hosts]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:American podcasters]] [[Category:American people of Lithuanian descent]] [[Category:Late night television talk show hosts]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Lexington, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Gordon College (Massachusetts) alumni]] [[Category:Comedians from Massachusetts]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]] [[Category:Lexington High School alumni]]
